newsitem.title: USA: NYS Pataki to end passenger tolls at Spring Valley.
newsitem.headline: NYS Pataki to end passenger tolls at Spring Valley.

text.p: New York State Gov George Pataki on Monday said the the 40-cent passenger toll for cars at Spring Valley will be abolished by July 18 as part of a plan to speed traffic on the Tappan Zee Bridge corridor.

The Republican governor, in prepared remarks, said the Thruway Authority's approach protected the the integrity of its bond covenants, contrasting it with what he called a "technically-flawed" bill that he veoted last year.

The Authority's bond covenants prohibit actions that negatively impact revenues. To satisfy these requirements and ensure the plan was "revenue-neutral," the agency proposed raising the toll paid by passengers who are not commuters at the Tappan Zee Bridge by 50 cents or 25 cents in each direction to $3 from $2.50, the governor said.

Eliminating the 40-cent toll will cut the cost of a round trip for commuters who drive on Spring Valley and the Tappan Zee by 80 cents. Drivers of passenger cars who are not commuting but who travel a round trip will save 30 cents.

The measure, which includes studying whether to completely remove the toll barrier at Spring Valley and build a new one for trucks at another site on Interstate 287, aimed to boost local use of the Thruway, relieve congestion on Route 59 in Spring Valley and improve air quality and reduce noise.
